root: ^“Good Morning, am I the first one here?”
^You reflect on the time, amused that he seems to think anyone else would even be up at this early of an hour.
^He is the first person you’ve seen…but will you choose to tell him as such?
^“I’ve seen plenty of other guests come through today.”
^ “What’s it to you? I thought moths were nocturnal…”

seen1: ^This is a blatant lie, but you have to find some way to keep yourself entertained in this dreary establishment.
^“That’s just great. I may already have a huge problem on my hands...”
^“Honestly, why does trouble always seem to follow my vacation leave!”
^You notice his irritability. Seeing guests unhappy even after check-in always gets you down. You can’t help but feel a little guilty.
seen2: ^“Excuse me? You’re far too nosy for a receptionist.”
^“I’m sure there are better things to do than pry into guests' personal matters.”
^You wish he was correct, but he couldn’t be more wrong.
^Small talk is the most riveting thing around here, even on good days.
^“In regards to your question, I get up when I please."
^You crack a small smile, which he doesn’t seem to find amusing.
^A moth that doesn’t sleep during the day? How times are changing.
seen3: ^“Splendid. There may still be time yet to fix this. Perhaps they merely haven’t arrived yet.”
^“My punctuality has always been a burden when it comes to situations like this.”
^The obvious bragging does not escape your attention. You wonder who they might be expecting.
lastnight: ^“Enough with the idle small talk, let's address the matter at hand.”
^“Although, it’s not like you seemed to be doing much before I arrived.”
^The pile of guests’ paperwork you still have left to complete agrees with him.
^You feel like he seems hesitant to ask you whatever is on his mind. He keeps glancing in the direction of your telephone with a worried expression.
^“I know I have already pried, but are you sure you haven’t seen anyone with the following description since last night?”
^“They would be wearing a tie with a little red pocket square, and be carrying with them a rather large briefcase…”
^“… a briefcase full of newly printed, half signed, Advanced Readers Copies of my newest book…”
^“Let me assure you this is a purely professional, not personal matter."
^"I have simply lost my Press Manager on the way here…somehow.”
^“I’m sure my publishers will compensate you for your troubles if you choose to help.”
^You try to recall the events of last night. He seems like an important figure, famous, even.
^Is it wise to be getting involved in whatever this mix up seems to be?
^“I'm afraid I can’t tell you that. Receptionist's honor!”
^“Nobody else matching that description stopped by.”
lastnight1: ^“Seriously? Is this what you call customer service in this part of the woods?”
^“I could really use even a tiny ounce of co-operation right now.”
^Oops. You seem to have annoyed him with your nonchalant act.
^That self improvement book lied to you. So much for suggesting that being aloof makes you seem more interesting to strangers.
^You cave and tell him what he wants to know.
^“Just kidding… I haven’t seen who you are looking for.”
lastnight2: ^“Sorry to break it to you, you were the last guest to check in last night.”
^Well.. apart from that frazzled reptile woman. She doesn’t seem to fit the description though.
managerlocation: ^“Ohhh dear, the books… Moth save me.”
^“I must have lost them on the way here.”
^“Yes… that’s the only logical explanation. Aubrey wouldn’t just abandon me like this.”
^They look around the lobby with an increasingly concerned expression.
^You feel like now is a good time to ask for some more context.
^“So Aubrey is the person you are looking for? And they are… your manager?”
^"Yes. My Press Manager to be exact. They were supposed to accompany me on my latest pre-release tour, but I wanted to take a little detour first…"
^"All below board, you see. Which is why it's rather inconvenient they have gotten lost with a briefcase full of unreleased books all conveniently sporting my name in large letters."
^“I knew I shouldn’t have flown in. They can never keep up with me during arial travel…”
^His answers have raised a million more questions for you. You suddenly recall his check-in slip mentioning he was an Author.
^Now doesn’t seem the time for more prying, as he seems incredibly on edge.
^ “Is there anything else I can do?”
^ You’ve met his type before. Best to leave him to his muttering.
managerloc1: ^“Moths no, you’ve proved yourself rather useless already.”
^“It’s not as if you can make a person suddenly appear, and that is the only thing that will currently solve my problem.”
^“Ugh, I need a cup of coffee. Where is the machine?”
^You decide to sheepishly point him in the direction of the single lonely Motel coffee station.
^“Down the hall and to the right.”
^… but by the time the words have left your mouth, he’s already stomped halfway down the corridor…
managerloc2: ^“I cannot believe I’ve lost my damn Press Manager… My publishers won’t like a word of this and I’m already on thin ice for straying from schedule.”
^“They might be even more mad about the books though… I am too, but less so.”
^“I can manage without that tasteless garbage being distributed under my name.”
^“Honestly, who thought the 'Roman Empire' was going to be more interesting than the Renaissance, or even the 1800s…”
^He doesn’t appear to be paying attention to you any more, but realises this far too late.
^“Pardon me, was I rambling off to myself again? I need to go back to my room and make some calls.”
sc1end: ^<i>Well…that was pretty peculiar. Sounds like a serious problem! Maybe he will return later?
